messageBody:
The question should be also, why is the method private? The most
obvious reason I can think of is to hide the method from a client class.
If I want to test a method that is private, I usually decide to make it
protected. That is the easiest and fastest way. If I still need to
have the method private in order to hide it from clients, I go with an
interface. In that case I can make sure that the client only uses what
I want to be seen and I am free in the implementation class to have a
more liberal visibility of methods.



Andreas
